choices.text: Neuritic plaques made of beta amyloid are found
Nucleus of Meynert is not affected

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about Alzheimer's disease?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nucleus of Meynert is not affected

 

The Nucleus of Meynert (a group of cholinergic neurons in the basal forebrain) is indeed affected in AD, leading to a decrease in acetylcholine, which contributes to the memory deficits seen in this disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Alzheimer's disease (AD) is a progressive neurodegenerative disease that primarily affects the elderly. The key findings in AD are:

 

Option A. Intracellular neurofibrillary tangles are seen: True. These are composed of hyperphosphorylated tau protein.

 

Option B. Neuritic plaques made of beta amyloid are found: True. These plaques are extracellular and are composed of beta-amyloid protein.

 

Option D. Short term memory is affected: True. This is one of the hallmark clinical features of AD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alzheimer's disease is the most common cause of dementia. It is characterized by both intracellular neurofibrillary tangles and extracellular neuritic plaques. Cholinergic deficits, especially from the degeneration of the Nucleus basalis of Meynert, play a significant role in the memory impairments observed in these patients.

questions.text: Which among the following has the highest airway resistance? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bronchi

 

Among the given options, bronchi (medium-sized airway) offer maximum resistance.

 

The best answer here is bronchi, as the other options suggest smaller airways and bronchi is the only medium-sized airway.

 

Since the airway branches in each generation exist in parallel rather than in series, smallest airway contributes little to overall resistance. As the parallel branching increases, the resistance decreases because the total cross-sectional diameter of small airways put together is high resulting in less resistance. Also, airflow velocity decreases substantially because the effective cross-sectional area increases (i.e., the flow becomes laminar).

 

Other factors affecting airway resistance:

 

  • Lung volume, as lung volume increases the resistance decreases and vice versa. Lung volume increases the trans airway pressure thus increasing the caliber of the airway.
  • Airway mucus, edema, and contraction of bronchial smooth muscle increase the airway resistance. Its clinical application is seen in asthma, bronchitis, and emphysema
  • The density and viscosity of inspired gas also contribute to airway resistance. A gas with more density imparts more resistance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alveolar duct and C. Respiratory bronchioles: These smaller airways have much lower resistance due to their large total cross-sectional area, which reduces resistance despite their small individual diameters.

 

Option D. Small bronchioles: Similar to the respiratory bronchioles, their high number and extensive branching reduce overall resistance.

 

Educational Objective

 

Bronchi, the medium-sized airways, have the highest airway resistance due to their relatively narrow diameter compared to the total cross-sectional area of smaller airways.

 

Airflow can be derived from Poiseuille- Hagen formula:

 

 

Where:

 

  • R is the resistance
  • is pie symbol
  • r is radius
  • is viscosity
  • L is length

 

According to Poisuille’s formula, Airway resistance is inversely proportional to the fourth power radius.

 

Poiseuille- Hagen formula suggests that the smallest airways are the major site of resistance.

questions.text: Coagulation profile monitoring is needed in therapy with which of the following drugs? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lepirudin

 

Lepirudin is a direct thrombin inhibitor that is used in multiple doses and produces unpredictable effects, that has the most serious side effect of bleeding. Therefore, it requires monitoring by aPTT.

 

Dabigatran is an oral direct thrombin inhibitor, Enoxaparin is a LMWH that acts by inhibiting factor Xa and factor IIa, whereas Fondaparinux acts only by inhibiting factor Xa only.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fondaparinux: Fondaparinux is a selective factor Xa inhibitor that does not usually require routine coagulation monitoring because it has a predictable anticoagulant response when used at standard doses.

 

Option B. Enoxaparin: Enoxaparin is a low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) that primarily inhibits factor Xa and to a lesser extent factor IIa (thrombin). Routine coagulation monitoring is generally not required with enoxaparin due to its predictable pharmacokinetic profile, though monitoring may be considered in certain populations (e.g., renal impairment, extremes of body weight).

 

Option C. Dabigatran: Dabigatran is an oral direct thrombin inhibitor that also does not typically require routine coagulation monitoring due to its predictable pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics. However, in specific clinical situations, such as suspected overdose or emergency surgery, monitoring may be necessary.

 

Educational Objective:

:

Lepirudin, a direct thrombin inhibitor, requires regular monitoring of the activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) due to its potential for unpredictable anticoagulant effects and the risk of serious bleeding.

choices.text: Iso-volumetric contraction
Slow filling at end of diastole
End of systole
Start of diastole

questions.text: 'c' wave in JVP is seen in which phase of cardiac cycle? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Iso-volumetric contraction

 

Explanation

 

'c' waves are produced by bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during the Iso-volumetric contraction of the right ventricle.

 

The isovolumetric contraction phase is characterized by a closed tricuspid valve and a still-closed pulmonary valve, which causes the pressure in the ventricle to rise rapidly without changing its volume.

 

 

Fig: Intra-arterial pressure changes during cardiac cycle. a, c, v= Positive wave x, x1, y= Negative waves

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Slow filling at end of diastole: Incorrect because this phase involves the heart filling with blood, not contracting.

 

Option C. End of systole: Incorrect as this phase corresponds to the onset of ventricular relaxation, not contraction.

 

Option D. Start of diastole: Incorrect because the start of diastole is marked by ventricular relaxation and opening of the atrioventricular valves for ventricular filling, not contraction.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Inhibition of calcineurin
AMP kinase stimulation
IMP dehydrogenase inhibition

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of cyclosporine? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Inhibition of calcineurin
 

  • Cyclosporine is an immunosuppressant drug that acts by inhibiting Calcineurin.
  • Calcineurin is a calcium/calmodulin-dependent phosphatase required for the induction of T cell lymphokine production and proliferation.
  • Cyclosporine inhibits calcineurin activity by forming a complex with cyclophilin, a cytoplasmic-receptor protein present in target cells, to form a cyclosporine-cyclophilin complex. This drug-receptor complex specifically and competitively binds to and inhibits calcineurin.
  • This, in turn, inhibits the translocation of a family of transcription factors (NF-AT), leading to reduced transcriptional activation of cytokine genes for interleukin (IL)-2 and other factors.
  • Ultimately, the proliferation of T lymphocytes is reduced, resulting in immunomodulation.
  • Indications: It is the most effective drug for the prevention of Graft rejection reaction. It is also used as a second line drug in autoimmune disease like severe Rheumatoid arthritis, uveitis, inflammatory bowel disease and dermatomyositis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. AMP kinase is stimulated by metformin used in treating T2DM
 

Option C. IMP dehydrogenase is inhibited by mycophenolate mofetil, also used in the prophylaxis of transplant rejection.

 

Option D. Dihydro-orotate dehydrogenase is inhibited by leflunomide, a pyrimidine synthesis inhibitor indicated for the management of rheumatoid arthritis in adults.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cyclosporine exerts its immunosuppressive effects by inhibiting calcineurin, thereby preventing the activation of T cells and reducing the production of cytokines such as IL-2. This mechanism is crucial for its role in preventing graft rejection and managing autoimmune diseases.

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about cutaneous anthrax, except: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Wool Sorter's disease

 

Explanation:

 

Wool Sorter's disease is NOT a feature of cutaneous anthrax but rather refers to pulmonary anthrax. Wool Sorter's disease is specifically the inhalational form of anthrax that occurs when spores are inhaled, typically among workers handling contaminated wool, hides, or other animal products. It affects the respiratory system, presenting with flu-like symptoms that progress to severe respiratory distress, and has historically had a very high mortality rate (approaching 100% if untreated).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Malignant pustule - This statement is true about cutaneous anthrax. The characteristic lesion of cutaneous anthrax is known as a "malignant pustule." This term describes the central necrotic, painless lesion that develops at the site of inoculation after spores enter through breaks in the skin.

 

Option B. Hide Porter's disease - This statement is true about cutaneous anthrax. "Hide Porter's disease" is another name for cutaneous anthrax, named after the occupational risk faced by workers who carried (ported) animal hides, which could be contaminated with anthrax spores.

 

Option C. Black eschar - This statement is true about cutaneous anthrax. The development of a black eschar is the hallmark of cutaneous anthrax. The lesion begins as a painless papule that vesiculates and eventually develops into a characteristic black, necrotic eschar surrounded by non-pitting edema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The three forms of anthrax have distinct clinical presentations and names: cutaneous anthrax (Hide Porter's disease, malignant pustule) presents with a characteristic painless black eschar; pulmonary anthrax (Wool Sorter's disease) presents with respiratory symptoms; and gastrointestinal anthrax affects the digestive tract after consuming contaminated meat.

questions.text: The 'Japanese Detergent Suicide Technique' involves the mixing of common household chemicals to produce: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Answer: A. H₂S and other poisonous gases

 

Explanation:

 

The 'Japanese Detergent Suicide Technique' involves mixing common household chemicals (typically an acid like toilet bowl cleaner with sulfur-containing products) to produce hydrogen sulfide (H₂S) and other toxic gases. H₂S is a highly toxic gas that inhibits cellular respiration by binding to cytochrome oxidase. This method became notorious in Japan where individuals would mix these chemicals in enclosed spaces like cars or small rooms, leading to rapid death by toxic gas inhalation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Deadly foam - The technique does not primarily produce a deadly foam. While some foaming may occur during the chemical reaction, the lethal component is the gaseous hydrogen sulfide released.

 

Option C. Deadly acidic compound - Though acids may be used in the reaction, the deadly element is not the acidic compound itself but rather the gaseous products (primarily H₂S) released from the chemical reaction.

 

Option D. Deadly fluid cyanide compound - The technique does not produce cyanide compounds. Hydrogen sulfide (H₂S) is chemically distinct from cyanide compounds, though both act as cellular asphyxiants by different mechanisms.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The 'Japanese Detergent Suicide Technique' produces hydrogen sulfide (H₂S) gas, which acts as a cellular poison by inhibiting cytochrome oxidase in the mitochondrial electron transport chain, leading to rapid asphyxiation and death.

questions.text: Respiratory distress syndrome is due to defect in which of the following cell?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Type 2 pneumocytes

 

One of the most characteristic findings in respiratory distress syndrome is failure of the respiratory epithelium to secrete adequate quantities of surfactant, a substance normally secreted into the alveoli that decreases the surface tension of the alveolar fluid, therefore allowing the alveoli to open easily during inspiration.

 

The surfactant-secreting cells are type II alveolar epithelial cells.

 

Production of the surfactant begins by week 20-24. It appears in the amniotic fluid between 28 and 32 weeks of gestation. Mature levels of the pulmonary surfactant are present usually after 35 weeks of gestation.

 

Antenatal corticosteroids are given to increase production of surfactant.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type 1 pneumocytes: Incorrect because although Type 1 pneumocytes cover a large surface area of the alveoli and are involved in the gas exchange process, they do not produce surfactant. The defect in Type 1 pneumocytes generally leads to issues with the structural integrity of the alveolar walls, not surfactant deficiency.

 

Option C. Alveolar capillary endothelial cells: Incorrect as these cells line the alveolar capillaries and are involved in the blood-air barrier for gas exchange. Defects in these cells can lead to issues like pulmonary edema but are not directly related to surfactant production or respiratory distress syndrome due to surfactant deficiency.

 

Option D. Bronchial mucosal epithelial cells: Incorrect because these cells line the bronchial passages and are primarily involved in mucous production and the removal of particulates and pathogens from inhaled air. They are not involved in surfactant production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Respiratory distress syndrome, especially in premature infants, is commonly due to insufficient surfactant production by Type 2 pneumocytes. This deficiency impedes the lungs' ability to expand properly, leading to respiratory distress. Management often includes the administration of exogenous surfactant and supportive care to enhance lung function until the infant's own cells can produce adequate surfactant.

choices.text: Rapid filling of the left ventricle

questions.text: The dicrotic notch on the aortic pressure curve is caused by?  (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Closing of the aortic valve

 

Explanation: 

 

The dicrotic notch is a small oscillation or wave that appears in the falling phase of the aortic pressure curve during the cardiac cycle. This notch is specifically caused by vibrations set up when the aortic valve snaps shut. The dicrotic notch occurs at the end of ventricular systole when the aortic pressure exceeds left ventricular pressure, causing the aortic valve to close. This closure creates a brief backward movement of blood and subsequent rebound, generating the characteristic notch in the aortic pressure tracing.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Closing of the mitral valve The mitral valve closes at the beginning of ventricular systole, not during the falling phase of aortic pressure. Mitral valve closure contributes to the first heart sound (S1) and occurs before ejection of blood into the aorta, so it cannot be responsible for the dicrotic notch.
  • Option B. Closing of the tricuspid valve The tricuspid valve closes at the beginning of right ventricular systole, similar to mitral valve closure. It has no direct effect on aortic pressure and occurs much earlier in the cardiac cycle than the dicrotic notch.
  • Option D. Rapid filling of the left ventricle Rapid filling of the left ventricle occurs during early diastole, after the aortic valve has closed. This ventricular filling phase follows the dicrotic notch rather than causing it, making this option incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The dicrotic notch is a distinctive feature on the aortic pressure curve that specifically marks the moment of aortic valve closure at the end of ventricular systole, representing the transition between systole and diastole.

questions.text: Most effective antiemetic for chemotherapy-induced vomiting is: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Granisetron

 

Granisetron is a 5-HT3 receptor antagonist that is highly effective for preventing chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting (CINV). These drugs have become the standard of care for managing moderate to highly emetogenic chemotherapy agents.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Domperidone: Domperidone is a dopamine receptor antagonist used for the treatment of nausea and vomiting, but it is generally not as effective as 5-HT3 receptor antagonists like Granisetron for managing chemotherapy-induced vomiting.

 

Option B. Tegaserod: Tegaserod is primarily used for treating irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) with constipation and is not an antiemetic. It acts as a 5-HT4 receptor agonist to promote gastrointestinal motility.

 

Option D. Doxylamine: Doxylamine is an antihistamine that can be used for nausea and vomiting during pregnancy, often in combination with pyridoxine (vitamin B6). It is not the most effective option for chemotherapy-induced vomiting.

 

Therefore, the most effective antiemetic for chemotherapy-induced vomiting is Granisetron, making option C the correct answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Granisetron, a 5-HT3 receptor antagonist, is the most effective antiemetic for preventing chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting (CINV). It is the standard of care for managing nausea and vomiting associated with moderate to highly emetogenic chemotherapy agents.

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic patient presents with an extremely painful lesion in the external ear accompanied by otorrhea that has not responded to antibiotics. Granulation tissue is observed in the external ear, and there is evidence of bony erosion along with facial nerve palsy. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Malignant Otitis Externa

 

Explanation:


The clinical presentation strongly indicates Malignant Otitis Externa (MOE), also known as necrotizing otitis externa. Key diagnostic features present in this case include: extreme pain in the external ear, otorrhea unresponsive to antibiotics, presence of granulation tissue in the external ear canal, bony erosion, facial nerve palsy, and importantly, a diabetic patient. MOE is primarily caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa infection and occurs most commonly in elderly diabetic patients or immunocompromised individuals.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nasopharyngeal carcinoma: This typically presents with nasal obstruction, epistaxis, conductive hearing loss due to eustachian tube dysfunction, and cranial nerve palsies (particularly CN V and VI) from skull base invasion. Primary symptoms would be in the nasopharynx rather than the external ear, and there would not be granulation tissue in the external ear canal.

 

Option C. Chronic suppurative otitis media: This involves a long-standing infection of the middle ear with tympanic membrane perforation and persistent discharge. While it can cause bone erosion and complications like facial palsy, it wouldn't present with granulation tissue in the external ear canal as the primary site of disease is the middle ear. The extreme pain described is also more characteristic of MOE.

 

Option D. Acute suppurative otitis media: This is an acute infection of the middle ear presenting with otalgia, fever, and sometimes otorrhea if the tympanic membrane ruptures. It doesn't cause bony erosion or facial nerve palsy in its typical presentation, and would generally respond to appropriate antibiotic therapy, unlike the case described.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Malignant otitis externa should be strongly suspected in elderly diabetic patients presenting with severe otalgia, otorrhea unresponsive to therapy, granulation tissue in the ear canal, and complications like facial nerve palsy or evidence of bony erosion.

questions.text: The endotoxin of which gram-negative bacterium does not play a role in the pathogenesis of the disease it causes? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Vibrio cholerae

 

Explanation:

 

Vibrio cholerae is the correct answer because unlike typical Gram-negative infections, the pathogenesis of cholera is primarily mediated by an exotoxin (cholera toxin) rather than its endotoxin. Cholera toxin activates adenylate cyclase in intestinal epithelial cells, leading to massive secretion of water and electrolytes, resulting in the characteristic profuse, watery "rice-water" diarrhea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. E. coli - The endotoxin (lipopolysaccharide) of E. coli plays a significant role in its pathogenesis, particularly in septic shock. The endotoxin activates inflammatory pathways, complement cascades, and can lead to fever, hypotension, and disseminated intravascular coagulation.

 

Option B. Klebsiella - The endotoxin of Klebsiella is a major virulence factor in its pathogenesis. During infection, Klebsiella's endotoxin contributes to the inflammatory response, potential septic shock, and tissue damage.

 

Option D. Pseudomonas aeruginosa - Endotoxin plays an important role in Pseudomonas infections. The lipopolysaccharide component of P. aeruginosa activates inflammatory responses contributing to tissue damage and systemic effects during infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While all Gram-negative bacteria contain endotoxin (lipopolysaccharide) in their cell walls, the relative importance of this component in disease pathogenesis varies. For Vibrio cholerae, the exotoxin (cholera toxin) is the primary virulence factor responsible for the characteristic clinical manifestations.

choices.text: Bicarbonate in the intracellular compartment
Calcium in the extracellular compartment

questions.text: Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium is mainly due to? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Intracellular proteins

 

Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium is mainly due to intracellular proteins.

 

The Gibbs-Donnan effect describes the unequal distribution of Diffusible charged ions on either side of a semipermeable membrane which occurs in the presence of impermeant charged ions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phosphate: While phosphate ions are present in both intracellular and extracellular compartments, they are not the primary cause of the Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium. Their concentrations do not significantly contribute to the electrochemical gradient and osmotic balance in the same way as intracellular proteins do.

 

Option B. Bicarbonate in the intracellular compartment: Bicarbonate ions are crucial for maintaining acid-base balance, but they are not the main factor in establishing the Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium. Their movement across membranes is more related to pH regulation rather than creating an electrochemical gradient due to impermeant ions.

 

Option C. Calcium in the extracellular compartment: Calcium ions are essential for various cellular functions, including muscle contraction and neurotransmission, but they do not play a primary role in the Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium. Their concentration differences across membranes are tightly regulated by channels and pumps, rather than by the presence of impermeant ions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

At Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium,

 

  • On each side of the membrane, each solution will be electrically neutral
  • The product of diffusible ions on one side of the membrane will be equal to the product of diffusible ions on the other side of the membrane
  • The electrochemical gradients produced by unequal distribution of charged ions produces a transmembrane potential difference which can be calculated using the Nernst equation
  • The presence of impermeant ions on one side of the membrane creates an osmotic diffusion gradient attracting water into that compartment.

 

Intracellular proteins are negatively charged non-permeable ions, then distribution of other permeable ions is affected in a predictable way (Donnan Effect) so that at equilibrium their concentration ratios are equal.

questions.text: Which Reflex is responsible for tachycardia during right atrial distension? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Bainbridge reflex

 

Explanation

 

Bainbridge reflex is a cardioaccelerator reflex that increases the heart rate when venous return is increased. Since this reflex arises from right atrium, it is also called right atrial reflex.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. J Reflex: Apnea followed by rapid breathing, bradycardia, and hypotension due to J receptor (C-receptor, juxta-pulmonary capillary receptor) stimulation.

 

Option B. Cushing Reflex: Incorrect because the Cushing reflex involves increased blood pressure, bradycardia, and respiratory depression in response to increased intracranial pressure, not right atrial distension.

 

Option C. Bezold-Jarisch Reflex: Bezold-Jarisch reflex is the reflex characterized by bradycardia and hypotension, caused by stimulation of chemoreceptors present in the wall of left ventricles by substances such as alkaloids. It is also called coronary chemoreflex. Vagal fibers form the afferent and efferent pathways of this reflex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Bainbridge reflex is responsible for inducing tachycardia in response to right atrial distension. It serves to adjust heart rate upward when venous return to the heart increases, ensuring optimal cardiac output and circulation efficiency.

questions.text: Which of the labeled structures in the given image represents the pelvic diaphragm? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. A

 

The structure marked "A" is the levator ani muscle which is the component of pelvic diaphragm.

 

Other structures marked in the above image are:

 

B: External anal sphincter

C: Obturator internus

D: Perianal fascia

 

Pelvic diaphragm -

 

The pelvic diaphragm is the muscular part of the pelvic floor. It connects to the pelvic wall on both sides, between the greater and lesser sciatic foramen. The pelvic diaphragm is formed by the levator ani and coccyges muscles, which define the lower limit of the true pelvis.

 

 

Pubococcygeus, iliococcygeus, and puborectalis combine to form Levator ani. The muscles in both sexes blend together posterior to the vagina and around the anus. The form in which the anococcygeal body attaches to the coccyx posterior to the anal aperture.

 

Urogenital hiatus is present anteriorly separating the muscles. This allows the urethra and vagina to pass through. Levator ani reinforces the external anal sphincter. In women, it functions as the vaginal sphincter.

 

The coccyges muscles are triangular in shape and form the posterior part of the pelvic diaphragm, one on each side. The apices are attached to the ischial spine tips. The bases connect to the coccyx and sacrum.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sphincter Ani Externus (External Anal Sphincter): This is a circular muscle that surrounds the anus. It's located below the level of the levator ani. It is innervated by the pudendal nerve, allowing for voluntary control over defecation.

 

Option C. Obturator Muscle: This term often refers to two muscles - obturator externus and obturator internus. They are situated on either side of the obturator membrane in the pelvis. Obturator Externus: Obturator nerve and Obturator Internus: Nerve to obturator internus (a branch of the sacral plexus).

 

Option D. Perianal Fascia: The perianal fascia is not a muscle but is the connective tissue located in the perianal region, around the anus. It's part of the deeper layers of the skin in this region.  It's associated with various potential spaces that can become sites of abscess formation if there's an infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The levator ani is the principal muscle of the pelvic floor and is composed of three parts: the puborectalis, the pubococcygeus, and the iliococcygeus. It is primarily innervated by the pudendal nerve and the S4 nerve root.

questions.text: Confusion assessment test is used in: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Delirium

 

The Confusion Assessment Method (often referred to as CAM) is a diagnostic tool specifically designed to identify delirium.

 

CAM is used primarily for the detection of delirium, especially in hospitalized or elderly patients. It evaluates features like acute onset and fluctuating course, inattention, disorganized thinking, and altered level of consciousness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dementia: While CAM can help differentiate delirium from dementia, it is not specifically designed for the diagnosis of dementia.

 

Option C. Schizophrenia: CAM is not used in the diagnosis or assessment of schizophrenia.

 

Option D. Depression: CAM is not used in the diagnosis or assessment of depression.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Confusion Assessment Method (CAM) is a tool specifically developed to detect delirium. Bedside examinations such as mini mental status examination (MMSE) are used to provide a measure of cognitive impairment.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 701.

questions.text: A young boy with a history of multiple blood transfusions presents with bone pain for the past 6 months. A peripheral smear showed sickle-shaped RBCs. Which of the following drugs are not used in the treatment of his condition? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Bebtelovimab

 

  • The given clinical features are suggestive of Sickle cell anemia. Voxelotor, hydroxyurea and L-glutamine are used for treatment of sickle cell anemia whereas Bebtelovimab is not used in in this condition.
  • Bebtelovimab is a new monoclonal antibody used for the treatment of COVID-19. It works by binding to the spike protein of the COVID-19 virus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Voxelotor: Is an inhibitor of hemoglobin S polymerase and stabilizer of sickle cell hemoglobin (HbS) that is used in the therapy of sickle cell disease.

 

Option C. Hydroxyurea: Improves fetal hemoglobin (HbF) and is the primary drug for controlling HbS in sickle cell disease. Thus, improving the oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood.

 

Option D. L-glutamine: Is a naturally occurring amino acid with antioxidant properties. It increases the availability of reduced glutathione which may lessen oxidative damage in sickle red blood cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bebtelovimab is not used in the treatment of sickle cell anemia; it is a monoclonal antibody used for COVID-19 treatment. In contrast, Voxelotor, Hydroxyurea, and L-glutamine are used in managing sickle cell anemia by improving hemoglobin function and reducing oxidative stress in red blood cells.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male patient on cancer chemotherapy developed neutropenia. Which of the following drug is used to increase the immunity in this person? (Fmge Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Filgrastim

 

Filgrastim is a G-CSF (Granulocyte Colony Stimulating Factor) that can be used for chemotherapy induced neutropenia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Darbepoetin: It is an Erythropoietin analogue which is used in the treatment of anemia due to CKD and bone marrow suppression.
 

Option C. Oprelvekin: It is an IL-11 analogue and stimulates the proliferation of megakaryocytes. It is useful in Thrombocytopenia.
 

Option D. Iron Dextran: It is a parenteral iron preparation which is used to treat Iron deficiency anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Filgrastim is the drug used to increase immunity in patients with chemotherapy-induced neutropenia. It works by stimulating the production of neutrophils, thereby reducing the risk of infection. Other drugs like darbepoetin, oprelvekin, and iron dextran are used for different hematological conditions and do not directly increase neutrophil counts or improve immunity in neutropenic patients.

choices.text: Cannot be differentiated serologically from T. pallidum

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Yaws is not true? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Spread by sexual transmission

 

Explanation:

 

Yaws is not spread by sexual transmission. It is a non-venereal treponematosis caused by Treponema pertenue that spreads through direct contact with infected skin lesions. The disease primarily affects children in tropical regions, with transmission occurring through skin-to-skin contact during play or other close physical contact. Unlike syphilis, which is sexually transmitted, yaws spreads through non-sexual contact primarily in rural communities with poor hygiene.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Caused by T. pertenue - This statement is true. Yaws is indeed caused by Treponema pertenue, which is a non-venereal Treponema species closely related to T. pallidum (the causative agent of syphilis). The spirochete morphologically resembles T. pallidum but has different transmission patterns and epidemiology.

 

Option C. Has cross immunity with syphilis - This statement is true. Yaws provides cross immunity with syphilis because both organisms share common antigens. This cross-immunity has epidemiological significance, as regions with high prevalence of yaws typically have lower rates of syphilis.

 

Option D. Cannot be differentiated serologically from T. pallidum - This statement is true. Standard serological tests cannot differentiate between antibodies produced in response to T. pallidum and those produced in response to T. pertenue infection. Both infections produce positive results in non-treponemal tests (VDRL, RPR) and treponemal tests (FTA-ABS, TPHA).

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Yaws is a non-venereal treponematosis caused by T. pertenue that spreads through direct skin contact, primarily affecting children in tropical regions, and while it shares many features with syphilis including cross-immunity and serological similarities, it differs fundamentally in its mode of transmission.

questions.text: Match the following teratogenic drugs with their teratogenic effects: (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 1-d, 2-c, 3-b, 4-a

 

The correctly matched pairs of teratogenic drugs and their effects is 1-d, 2-c, 3-b, 4-a.

 

  1. Lithium is used in the treatment of bipolar disorders and prophylaxis of mania. It is c/I in pregnancy as it leads to Ebstein’s anomaly in the fetus, which is characterised by arterialization of the right ventricle and a box shaped heart.
  2. Warfarin leads to defect in the growth of the cartilage (chondrodysplasia punctata) characterized by depressed nasal bridge, stippled epiphyses etc. Warfarin embryopathy is maximally seen when it is used between 6-9 weeks.
  3. Thalidomide causes proximal limb defect or Phocomelia. Thalidomide acts via inhibiting angio-genesis, inhibiting cereblon and suppressing immune responses.
  4. Chloramphenicol inhibits peptidyl transferase. It causes Bone Marrow suppression and leads to grey baby syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The teratogenic effects of certain drugs is crucial for managing medication use during pregnancy. Lithium can cause Ebstein’s anomaly, Warfarin is associated with saddle nose and growth retardation, Thalidomide causes limb malformations, and Chloramphenicol can lead to Grey Baby Syndrome.

questions.text: The stroke volume depends on end-diastolic volume. This is best represented as?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Length-tension relationship

 

The relationship between end-diastolic volume and stroke volume is best represented by length-tension relationship.

 

Frank-Starling mechanism states that the greater the heart muscle is stretched during filling, the greater is the force of contraction and the greater the quantity of blood pumped into the aorta or, stated another way: Within physiologic limits, the heart pumps all the blood that returns to it by the way of the veins.

 

When an extra amount of blood flows into the ventricles, the cardiac muscle itself is stretched to greater length. This in turn causes the muscle to contract with increased force because the actin and myosin filaments are brought to a more nearly optimal degree of overlap for force generation. Therefore, the ventricle, because of its increased pumping, automatically pumps the extra blood into the arteries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The relationship between end-diastolic volume and stroke volume in the heart is best described by the length-tension relationship, which underlies the Frank-Starling mechanism. This principle explains how increased filling of the heart leads to greater contraction force and increased stroke volume.

questions.text: A woman with right-sided loss of sensations of both the upper and lower limb complains of shooting pain from her fingers to the right shoulder and a burning sensation when touching cold water. Motor functions are normal. Which of the following structures is likely to be involved? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Thalamus

 

The given clinical stem of a hemi-sensory loss and severe excruciating pain of the affected areas is suggestive of thalamic pain syndrome also known as Dejerine Roussy syndrome. Hence, thalamus marked as B is most likely to be involved.

 

The thalamus is a paired structure, with one thalamus on each side of the brain. It relays sensory and motor signals to the cerebral cortex and regulates consciousness, sleep, and alertness. The thalamus has multiple nuclei, each serving different functions. The ventral posterior nucleus, for instance, is vital for relaying somatosensory information. If the thalamus is damaged, it can lead to loss of sensation, and in certain cases, even cause the burning, shooting pain and abnormal temperature sensations described in the scenario, which aligns with the symptoms of thalamic syndrome.

 

 

The structures marked in the image are:

 

Option A.  A- Internal capsule

 

Option B. B- Thalamus

 

Option C. C- Subthalamic nucleus

 

Option D. D- Substantia nigra

 

Lesion in other three structures will lead to motor deficit and in question it is clearly mentioned that there is no motor deficit, only sensory deficit is the which  clearly indicates that the lesion lies in thalamus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Internal capsule: The internal capsule is a bundle of white matter fibers that separates the caudate nucleus and the thalamus from the lenticular nucleus (putamen and globus pallidus). The anterior limb separates the head of the caudate from the lenticular nucleus, while the posterior limb separates the thalamus from the lenticular nucleus. It contains ascending and descending axonal fibers running between the cerebral cortex and the brainstem/spinal cord. Damage to the internal capsule, especially its posterior limb, can cause contralateral hemiparesis or hemiplegia (motor deficits). However, the woman's motor functions are described as normal, making this a less likely option given the scenario.

 

Option C. Subthalamic nucleus: The subthalamic nucleus is part of the basal ganglia circuit and is specifically associated with motor function. Lesions of the subthalamic nucleus, particularly on one side, might result in hemiballismus, which is characterized by violent, flinging movements of the contralateral limbs. It is not typically associated with sensory disturbances, or the pain described in the scenario.

 

Option D. Substantia nigra: The substantia nigra is in the midbrain and plays a critical role in reward, addiction, and movement. It contains dopamine-producing neurons. The degeneration of these neurons is a hallmark of Parkinson's disease. Lesions in the substantia nigra would primarily produce motor symptoms, such as rigidity, bradykinesia, and tremors. It would not typically lead to the sensory disturbances described in the scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The thalamic pain syndrome is caused by the occlusion of these thalamic and thalamogeniculate branches. C/L hemisensory loss, which begins as numbness and escalates to cause intense burning pain in the affected areas, is what distinguishes it.

 

A thalamic lesion results in a breakdown in communication between the brain's afferent route and cortex because the thalamus serves as the site for the relay of sensory information between the periphery and cortex. The healing process following a thalamic infarct is painful.

questions.text: The structures marked in the image below are found in the epithelial lining of all of the following sites, except? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Epididymis

 

The picture depicts an arrow mark pointing in the direction of the cilia. All of the structures listed as choices have ciliated lining epithelia, with the exception of the epididymis, which has pseudostratified columnar epithelium with stereocilia, that’s play a role in sperm maturation and storage.

 

The given image is a histological section of the epididymis showing the pseudostratified columnar epithelium with stereocilia.

 

 

Cilia are minute hair-like projections, while stereocilia are very long, thick microvilli measuring about 5-10 um in length.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oviduct (Fallopian Tube): The oviduct, also known as the Fallopian tube, is a part of the female reproductive system. It contains ciliated epithelium, which helps in the transport of the egg from the ovary to the uterus. The cilia in the oviduct assist in moving the egg and help in the fertilization process.

 

Option C. Bronchi: The bronchi are part of the respiratory system and are responsible for conducting air to and from the lungs. They contain ciliated epithelium to help move mucus and trapped particles out of the respiratory tract.

 

Option D. Ependyma : it is a type of neuroglial cell that lines the ventricles of the brain and the central canal of the spinal cord. It contains ciliated epithelium, which assists in the circulation of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) within the central nervous system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ciliated epithelium:

 

  • The epithelium bears cilia, which moves in a coordinated fashion, and help in the movement of the mucus, or propel the movement of any other structures such as ova or spermatozoa.
  • The ciliated columnar epithelium is found in most of the respiratory tract, the uterus, and the uterine tube (oviduct), efferent ductules of the testis, parts of the middle ear and auditory tube; the ependyma lining the central canal of the spinal cord and the ventricles of the brain.
  • The pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium is seen in the trachea and in large bronchi.

questions.text: Endolymphatic hydrops is typically associated with which of the following conditions? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. A)  Meniere's disease

 

Explanation: 

 

Endolymphatic hydrops is the pathophysiological basis of Meniere's disease. It is characterized by excessive accumulation of endolymph in the inner ear, causing distension of the membranous labyrinth. This directly correlates with the classic clinical symptoms seen in Meniere's disease: episodic vertigo, fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, and tinnitus and aural fullness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Otosclerosis: This is a condition with irregular spongy bone formation around the oval window, leading to fixation of the stapes footplate. It causes a conductive hearing loss due to impeded sound transmission. Otosclerosis has no relationship with endolymphatic hydrops or the balance mechanism.

 

Option C. Acoustic Neuroma: This is a benign tumor that arises from the inferior vestibular nerve in the internal auditory canal. It causes progressive unilateral sensorineural hearing loss and tinnitus. It is not associated with endolymphatic hydrops or fluctuating symptoms like those seen in Meniere's disease.

 

Option D. Cholesteatoma: This is a "skin in the wrong place" - keratinizing squamous epithelium in the middle ear cleft. It causes a destructive process in the middle ear with bone erosion and conductive hearing loss. It has no connection with endolymphatic hydrops.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Endolymphatic hydrops is the hallmark pathological finding in Meniere's disease, causing episodic symptoms of vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss, and aural fullness due to increased pressure in the inner ear's endolymphatic system.

questions.text: An elderly gentleman has presented with symptoms of difficulty swallowing, regurgitation, bad breath, and cough. He also exhibits bilateral lung crepitations upon examination. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Zenker's Diverticulum

 

Explanation:

 

Zenker's diverticulum is a pulsion diverticulum where pharyngeal mucosa herniates through Killian's dehiscence (a weak area between two parts of the inferior constrictor muscle). This condition typically affects patients over 60 years of age, matching our elderly patient's demographic. The classic symptoms include dysphagia (difficulty swallowing), regurgitation of undigested food (especially at night when recumbent), halitosis (bad breath), and cough with aspiration pneumonia (explaining the bilateral lung crepitations).

 

Visual Support

 

Zenker's diverticulum occurs when herniation of pouch starts in the midline. It is at first behind the esophagus and then comes to lie on its left. The mouth of the sac is wider than the opening of esophagus, so food preferentially enters the sac.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Schatzki Ring: This is a narrow ring of tissue at the lower end of the esophagus and would not cause regurgitation of undigested food or aspiration pneumonia. It typically presents with intermittent dysphagia for solids only, not the constellation of symptoms described.

 

Option C. Corkscrew Esophagus: This is a motility disorder (diffuse esophageal spasm) characterized by non-peristaltic contractions. While it can cause dysphagia, it does not lead to regurgitation of undigested food, halitosis, or aspiration pneumonia as seen in this patient.

 

Option D. Plummer-Vinson Syndrome: This condition is characterized by hypochromic microcytic anemia, dysphagia, and esophageal webs. It typically affects women in their 40s and 50s, not elderly men. It is not associated with regurgitation, halitosis, or aspiration pneumonia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zenker's diverticulum should be suspected in elderly patients presenting with dysphagia, regurgitation of undigested food, halitosis, and respiratory complications due to aspiration, as the pouch traps food that can later be regurgitated and aspirated.
